page.title: 02FARMING The Salisbury Estate
page.content: {THE SALISBURY ESTATE _ WOODLAND The Salisbury Estate has 1,400 acres of mixed woodland and 2,450 acres of arable land. The trees are mainly broad_leafed trees and many are hundreds of years old. In one of the ancient woods hornbeams have been pollarded for extra wood. One tall straight oak is worth one thousand pounds and is highly suitable for veneers (thin sheets of wood to cover chipboard). Queen Elizabeth I heard the news that she was queen under one of the ancient oaks. Each year 7 or 8 acres are replanted. In 1977 the Coronation Plantation of fir trees was planted out. Many lime trees on the avenues need replacing. Mistletoe likes to grow on these trees. The most common trees to be found on the estate are ash, oak, lime, hornbeam, western hemlock and Scots pine.
